Pre-Game Insights: India will be wary of the threat the stubborn New Zealand possess.
A lot will depend on the fearless approach of Indian openers -- Rohit and Shubman Gill.
Virat Kohli is now the top run-getter in the tournament with 593 runs, and the landmark of 50 ODI hundreds is waiting to be reached.
Kohli would also like to break the semifinal jinx after getting dismissed for one in the 2019 and 2015 edition.
India will also be delighted to see their middle-order batters KL Rahul and Shreyas Iyer hitting top form ahead of the semis.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The teams batting second at this venue have invariably lost early wickets in clusters under lights with the new ball moving dangerously in the air and off the deck.
Both India and New Zealand have bowlers who can inflict severe damage with the new ball.
India's bowling attack has been unplayable when on song, with Mohammed Shami and Mohammed Siraj being unplayable when on song.
New Zealand have enough depth and experience to counter the marauding India bowlers.

The young Rachin Ravindra (565 runs) is the find of the tournament, but Devon Conway is short of big scores â€” his unbeaten 152 against England in the tournament opener was the only time he scored fifty or above.
Others: India will be aware that any slip up at the Wankhede Stadium will be viewed as a national catastrophe, shattering a billion hearts.

Captain Rohit and coach Rahul Dravid, two individuals who know all about the pitfalls of heavy expectations, will have to keep their outfit calm, nestled away from the fear of failure in a crunch match.
The pressure emanating out of those enormous expectations placed on them, also heightened by their league phase bull run, will be a challenge for India.
The Kiwis also had the measure of India in the ICC WTC Final in 2021, if one needs more attestation of the Kiwis' grip over the latter in global events.
